metadata.synopsis: Matt (Richard Gere) and John (William Devane), U.S. soldiers stationed in England during World War II, are both beginning affairs with British women, but they soon find their romances complicated by moral dilemmas and a clash of cultures. Jean (Lisa Eichhorn), a girl from a working class family, has caught Matt's eye, and John is trying to woo the elegant Helen (Vanessa Redgrave). However, both woman are already involved with local men who have left for the front.

reviews: It's soft, sort of spongy and so bland that you may well remember the scenery better than anything that happens in front of it.
Yanks remains an unusually appealing and ingratiating movie.
Director John Schlesinger has done a beautiful job with both cast and craft in Yanks, a multiple love story set in England in World War II. Yet little that's exciting ever happens in the picture.
Yanks is so much better than I expected that I hope I don't overrate it.
Yanks has a richness to it in both its technical and its human elements. Many of the episodes shine with emotional clarity and understanding, and they all reflect the sheen of Schlesinger's craft.

In every decade, a truly memorable motion picture comes along that, sometimes, if we're lucky, can enrich our lives. Yanks will be the one from the 1970s that future audiences and historians will remember, and cherish.
Though some of the photography is stunning and the mood of wartime Europe is warmly rendered, this is not a movie to write home about.
This pleasing effort from director John Schlesinger glows with a homely period charm, but never descends into sentimentality.
The mise-en-scène is good, as well as the actors, gags, and landscapes. [Full Review in Spanish]

Yanks, a tribute to sentimental war movies as much as to the camaraderie of war, concentrates on murmurs of the middle-class heart. And in its soft-spoken fidelity to the domestic emotions, it is indeed gorgeous.
Big looking, expensive, production starring Richard Gere is hardly worth it.
Good cast, scrupulous period reconstruction, and sentimentality; but it doesn't do much to redeem Schlesinger from the 'less-than-meets-the-eye' category.
A great period film, full of authenticity. A fine early performance by Gere.
Finely made John Schlesinger film is worth another look.
Yanks charts the difficulties of wartime love affairs.
